Comments_List: I improved my ability to read and understand papers and to propose new experiments based on past work. It also improved my scientific writing and structuring of ideas in my writing.

I gained a lot of knowledge about various fields and techniques within Neuroscience, which provided insight into what I am more and less interested in for my own research. I also improved my scientific reading and writing skills.

strong: breadth and depth of reading, having diverse topics/profs. great TAs and leading profs

weak: essays could be better served as mini specific aims/grants practice. journal club style is good, but class size was too large to be truly effective

I really liked the format of the course and clearly it has been mostly unchanged for a reason because it seems very successful to me. 

The one suggestion I would have is to maybe stress a bit higher expectations in discussion early on, but I know it has to be balanced with encouraging everyone to contribute.
Our class was quite large which made the Tuesday group discussions difficult. There should be clearer expectations for the essays at the beginning of the year.
yes, great for any neuro phd student
Yes, I really enjoyed this course and thought it did a fantastic job improving my abilities.

I learned a great deal in this class, particularly at the end going through essay revisions. The class was definitely worth it, but it is not easy and takes a great deal of time. Students should be aware of the effort and time they will need to put into it, but I do think it's helpful and provides a good overview of the field, getting to see work from various faculty members, and practice in writing.
